abstract.title: Abstract
abstract.p: This chapter provides an overview of reductions in the emission of greenhouse gases (GHGs) that will be needed to achieve either the target (1.5 Â°C warming) or upper limit (2.0 Â°C warming) of the Paris Climate Agreement. We quantify how much energy must be produced, either by renewables that do not emit significant levels of atmospheric GHGs or via carbon capture and sequestration (CCS) coupled to fossil fuel power plants, to meet forecast global energy demand out to 2060. For the Representative Concentration Pathway (RCP) 4.5 GHG emission trajectory to be matched, which is necessary for having a high probability of achieving the Paris target according to our Empirical Model of Global Climate (EM-GC), then the world must transition to production by renewables of 50 % of total global energy by 2060. For the RCP 2.6 GHG emission trajectory to be matched, which is necessary to achieve the Paris upper limit according to general circulation models (GCMs), then 88 % of the energy generated in 2060 must be supplied either by renewables or combustion of fossil fuels coupled to CCS. We also quantify the probability of achieving the Paris target in the EM-GC framework as a function of future CO2 emissions. Humans can emit only 82, 69, or 45 % of the prior, cumulative emissions of CO2 to have either a 50, 66, or 95 % probability of achieving the Paris target of 1.5 Â°C warming. We also quantify the impact of future atmospheric CH4 on achieving the goals of the Paris Climate Agreement.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
Humankind has benefited enormously from the energy provided by the combustion of fossil fuelsfossil fuels. The solid form (coalcoal) initially supplied heat and now provides a considerable portion of the worldâs electricityelectricity; the liquid form (petroleumpetroleum) fuels our vehiclestransportation of transportationtransportation; and the gaseous form (methanemethane, or natural gasnatural gas) is used to supply heatheating, generate electricity, and power transportation vehiclestransportation (Fig. 4.1). If you are reading this sentence indoors or electronically, it is probable that the electricity used to power the lights in your room or the screen of your device originated from heat released upon combustion of fossil fuelfossil fuels, which generated steam to drive a turbine.1 The combustion of fossil fuelfossil fuels to power past societies has led to the build-up of atmospheric carbon dioxide (CO2carbon dioxide). Removal of forests due to slash and burn agricultureagriculture has also had a considerable effect on atmospheric CO2carbon dioxide (Fig. 4.1). While it is easy to demonize fossil fuels with statements such as âCO2carbon dioxide is the greatest waste product of modern societyâ, we must not lose sight of the enormous benefit humankind has gained from the energy supplied upon combustion of the solid, liquid, and gaseous forms of fossil fuels, plus of course the cropsagriculture grown on land that once used to be forested.2Fig. 4.1
Sources of atmospheric CO2carbon dioxide. Emissions of atmospheric CO2carbon dioxide from land use changeland use change, combustion of solid (coalcoal), liquid (petroleumpetroleum), and gaseous (methane) forms of fossil fuelfossil fuels, as well as cement manufacturing and flaring. See Methods for further information

The reliance on fossil fuelsfossil fuels to pave our highways, construct and heat our buildings, allow us to visit foreign lands, and power our devices has been driven by two primary factors: the availability of vast reservoirs of readily accessible stocks of this resource and the considerable amount of energy released via the relatively simple combustion process. Alas, the world is now in a bind. Globally averaged atmospheric CO2carbon dioxide, which had a pre-industrialpre-industrial value of 280 parts per million (ppm), has now reached 404 ppm and is rising.3 Earthâs climate has warmed, primarily due to rising atmospheric CO2carbon dioxide.4 Unless society is able to soon implement provision of electricityelectricity, transportationtransportation, heat, and industrial energy on a massive, global scale that releases little or no GHGsgreenhouse gases to the atmosphere, we are on a course where the world will experience dire effects of climate change (Lynas 2008).

In this chapter we provide a quantitative analysis of the transformation of energy production that must be put in place for successful implementation of the Paris Climate AgreementParis Climate Agreement. Global warming projections based on the atmospheric, oceanic general circulation models (GCMsgeneral circulation model) that participated in Climate Model Intercomparison Project Phase 5 (CMIP5Climate Model Intercomparison Project Phase 5) (Taylor et al. 2012) indicate that achieving Paris Climate Agreement upper limit of 2 Â°C warming will require GHG emissions to follow the Representative Concentration Pathway (RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway) 2.6 trajectory (van Vuuren et al. 2011; Rogelj et al. 2016a). We consider both RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 2.6 (van Vuuren et al. 2011) and RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 4.5 (Thomson et al. 2011) emission scenarios in this chapter. Table 4.1 provides present and future atmospheric mixing ratios of CO2carbon dioxide and CH4methane, from both RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 4.5 and RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 2.6. Strict reductions in the anthropogenic emission of both GHGsgreenhouse gases will be needed to achieve either of the RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 4.5 or RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 2.6 trajectories.Table 4.1

Much of the focus in this chapter is on emissions of CO2carbon dioxide because this gas is the primary driver of climate change. We first compare projections of emissions of CO2carbon dioxide associated with world energy demand developed by the US Energy Information Administration (EIA) to the emissions that will be needed to achieve the RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 4.5 and RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 2.6 pathways. We then use satellite observations of light visible from space at night, known as night lightsnight lights, to illustrate the economic disparityeconomic disparity between various parts of the world. For reductions of GHG emissions to occur on a scale to reach RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 4.5, the developed world must transition to a massive use of renewable energyrenewable energy, not only to generate electricityelectricity, but also to supply heatheating and a considerable portion of other energy needs. If the developing world is to electrify and industrialize, then this will have to happen in a manner that relies heavily on the use of renewable energy, rather than combustion of fossil fuelsfossil fuels, to have a good chance of achieving the upper limit, much less the target, of the Paris Climate AgreementParis Climate Agreement. For the GHG emission reductions of RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 2.6 to be achieved, carbon capture and sequestrationcarbon capture and sequestration as well as the massive transition to renewablesrenewable energy will need to be implemented on a global scale.

We conclude by presenting an analysis of the transient climate response to cumulative CO2carbon dioxide emissions (TCREtransient climate response to cumulative CO2 emissions) (Allen et al. 2009; Rogelj et al. 2016b; MacDougall and Friedlingstein 2015), a policy relevant metric highlighted in the Summary for Policy Makers of IPCCIntergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (2013). Estimates of TCREtransient climate response to cumulative CO2 emissions from our EM-GC are compared to values from the CMIP5Climate Model Intercomparison Project Phase 5GCMsgeneral circulation model. Finally, we also provide an assessment of the impact of future growth in CH4methane, independent of CO2carbon dioxide, on the probability of achieving the Paris Climate AgreementParis Climate Agreement.

sec.title: World Energy Needs
sec.p:
Increasing demand for energy, as populations expandpopulationgrowth and standards of living rise, poses a significant challenge to the successful implementation of the Paris Climate AgreementParis Climate Agreement. Figure 4.2a shows a projection of global energy consumption from various sources, in units of 1015 British Thermal Units (BTU),5 provided by the US EIA.6 This agency forecasts a 70 % increase in world energy consumption in 2040, relative to 2012. We have extrapolated the EIA projections, which stop in 2040, out to 2060 using linear fits. This extrapolation is conducted because successful implementation of the Paris Climate Agreement will require wholesale transformations in how energy is produced by year 2060.Fig. 4.2
World energy consumption and CO2carbon dioxide emissions, business as usualbusiness as usual. (a) Historical (1990â2012) and projected (2012â2040) global energy consumption as a function of fuel source, from the US Energy Information Administration (EIA) and a linear extrapolation of these values out to 2060; (b) CO2carbon dioxide emissions from the coalcoal, natural gasnatural gas, and liquid fuel components of world energy consumption, provided by EIA for 1990â2040 and extrapolated to 2060, compared to emissions from these sources from RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 4.5 and RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 8.5. Numbers to the far right of each wedge are percent of total, for year 2060. See Methods for further information

Figure 4.2b compares the EIA projection of emissions of CO2carbon dioxide from combustion of coalcoal, natural gasnatural gas, and liquid fossil fuelsfossil fuels needed to meet global energy consumption (colored wedges) to emissions of CO2carbon dioxide from RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 4.5 and RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 8.5 (lines). Again, the EIA estimates extend only to 2040. We have also extrapolated the EIA emission estimates to 2060, for reasons that will soon become apparent. For simplicity, we assume that renewablesrenewable energy denote a means of producing energy for which atmospheric release of GHGsgreenhouse gases is negligible. At the end of this section, potential fallacies of this assumption for renewablesrenewable energy are presented. We also assume nuclear energynuclear energy poses no significant burden to atmospheric GHGsgreenhouse gases.

Figure 4.2b shows that if the world follows a business as usualbusiness as usual approach, emissions of CO2carbon dioxide from the combustion of fossil fuelsfossil fuels will fall between RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 4.5 and RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 8.5. The EIA projections are based on forecasts of demand, availability of various technologies, and market forces. There is no attempt to meet any particular climate change goal in this EIA forecast. The good news, we suppose, is that market forces, perhaps combined with environmentalism that acts through the market, appear to be driving the world away from RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 8.5. The bad news, however, is that the gap between projected emissions of CO2carbon dioxide and RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 4.5 is significant in 2040, and grows thereafter.

Figure 4.3 illustrates the dramatic transformation that will have to occur for emissions of CO2carbon dioxide to follow RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 4.5 (Thomson et al. 2011) over the 2030â2060 time period. Implicit in the calculations throughout this chapter is the assumption that EIA energy demand projections are met (see Methods for detailed description of how the calculations are conduced). Figure 4.3a shows that for RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 4.5 CO2carbon dioxide emissions to be met, the world must place itself on a trajectory whereby half of its energy needs: that is, half of all energy used for industryindustry, transportationtransportation, heat, electricityelectricity, etc., will be realized by renewablesrenewable energy that emit little to no GHGsgreenhouse gases by year 2060. All of the analyses in this chapter extend to 2060 because, quite simply, unless the world soon places itself on this trajectory, it will not be possible to keep global emissions of CO2carbon dioxide below those of RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 4.5.Fig. 4.3
World energy consumption and CO2carbon dioxide emissions, modified to meet RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 4.5. Same as Fig. 4.2, except the sum of CO2carbon dioxide emissions from coalcoal, natural gasnatural gas, and liquid fossil fuelsfossil fuels has been modified to match RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 4.5 (Thomson et al. 2011) starting in year 2030. For point of comparison, global energy demand used in the design of RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 4.5 is shown by the four black circles on the top panel. The gap between the EIA-based projection of energy demand and that which can no longer be provided by the combustion of fossil fuels under has been allocated to renewable sources that presumably do not release GHGsgreenhouse gases. See Methods for further information

The EIA energy demand forecast is, interestingly, quite similar to that used in the design of RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 4.5. The four circles in Fig. 4.3a show energy estimates given in Fig. 4.4a of Thomson et al. (2011). While development of energy produced by renewablesrenewable energy was an important component of the original RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 4.5 design, their projection has energy from hydropowerhydropower, solar, wind, plus geothermal being only ~32 % of the global energy total by end of century.

The reason our projection for the energy share from renewablesrenewable energy, 50 % by 2060, differs so much from the RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 4.5 projection of 32 % by 2100 can be summarized in one word: Fukushima. The Thomson et al. (2011) paper was submitted during September 2010 and was likely in its final stage of review at the time of the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant accident, which occurred during early March 2011. Their RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 4.5 design included a sizeable slice for growing energy demand to be met by expansion of nuclear energynuclear energy. Our projections for 2060, on the other hand, rely on extrapolation of the latest EIA projection of nuclear energy from 2030 to 2040. By 2060, nuclear energy is projected to supply only 5.7 % of world energy needs.7 We do not allow nuclear energy to grow to accommodate achievement of the RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 4.5 emissions of CO2carbon dioxide. As such, if global emissions of CO2carbon dioxide are to meet their RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 4.5 target, there needs to be a more rapid transition torenewable energyrenewable energy than Thomson et al. (2011) had envisioned.

Examination of the present state of affairs for renewablesrenewable energy casts this challenge in stark terms. Figure 4.4a shows a breakdown of supply of energy from renewablesrenewable energy for the EIA business as usualbusiness as usual projection from two categories: combustion of biomass (dark green) and all other sources (light green). Although it is not commonly appreciated, the primary source of energy from renewablesrenewable energy throughout the world happens to be combustion of biomass (Kopetz 2013). Much of the developing world heatsheating and cooks using energy derived by burning wood. Energy produced in this manner is classified as renewable, by EIA and others, because the carbon in the combusted fuel had been in the atmosphere not that long ago.8 Hydropower is the largest source of electricityelectricity from renewablesrenewable energy, but total global energy provided by combustion of wood dwarfs that from hydropowerhydropower.9 Unfortunately, combustion of wood for heat and cooking in the developing world imposes a serious toll on public health, especially for women and children (Wickramasinghe 2003; Schilmann et al. 2015). Some have proposed expansion of energy from biomass to meet future energy demand (Kopetz 2013). Such an effort will only be tenable if it is conducted in a manner that prevents human exposure to smoke and particulate exhaust. In addition, the generation of energy from biofuelsbiofuels places enormous demand on land use, with the potential to impact food production (Rathmann et al. 2010).Fig. 4.4
World energy consumption, renewablesrenewable energy. (a) Historical (1990â2012) and projected (2012â2040) global energy consumption from biomass burning (bottom wedge) and other forms of renewablesrenewable energy (top wedge) from the US EIA and a linear extrapolation of these values out to 2060; (b) the biomass burning wedge is the same as used in the top panel. The other forms of renewablesrenewable energy wedge shows how much energy must be produced, by forms of renewable energyrenewable energy other than biomass burning (i.e., hydropowerhydropower, solar, wind, and geothermal), to account for the total amount of renewable energy needed to meet RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 4.5 in 2060. See Methods for further information

Figure 4.4b shows the extraordinary, rapid growth of the non-biomass forms of renewable energyrenewable energy that will be required in the next four decades to enable emissions of CO2carbon dioxide to follow RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 4.5. Our projections are based on the assumption that the EIA energy demand projection will be met. Also, we have forced our biomass forecast to match that of EIA due to the severe harm to public health caused by the present implementation of biomass combustion (Wickramasinghe 2003; Schilmann et al. 2015). Perhaps the growth in energy demand projected by EIA can be dampened due to improvements in the efficiency of buildings, conservation, electrification of the vehicletransportation fleet,10 and a decline in population growthpopulationgrowth. However, it is hard to envision any of these factors dramatically altering the message of Fig. 4.4. Thus, the choice is clear: either the world charts a course towards supplying about half of total, global energy by renewablesrenewable energy around year 2060, or CO2carbon dioxide emissions will exceed those of RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 4.5.

The majority of the climate modeling community believes that for the 2 Â°C global warmingglobal warming upper limit of the Paris Climate AgreementParis Climate Agreement to be achieved, CO2carbon dioxide emissions must be reduced to match those of RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 2.6 (van Vuuren et al. 2011). As detailed in Chap. 2, forecasts of global warming conducted using our Empirical Model of Global Climate suggest the Paris targetParis Climate Agreement will likely be met under RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 4.5. Regardless, we now extend our forecast to RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 2.6.

Figure 4.5 illustrates the transformations that will have to occur to match the RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 2.6 emissions of CO2carbon dioxide (van Vuuren et al. 2011). The design of RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 2.6 employed carbon capture and sequestration (CCScarbon capture and sequestration) (IPCCIntergovernmental Panel on Climate Change2005), in addition to supply of energy from renewablesrenewable energy, to place the world on a low CO2carbon dioxide emission trajectory. There are many interpretations of CCScarbon capture and sequestration (NRC 2015). For our purposes, we will interpret CCScarbon capture and sequestration to mean the ability to remove carbon from the exhaust stream of power plants and industrial boilers and then isolate this carbon from the atmosphere, if not permanently then for many centuries. The light blue, orange, and dark blue wedges in Fig. 4.5b represent the energy that can be produced by combustion of fossil fuelsfossil fuels that are not operated using CCScarbon capture and sequestration, in order for the sum of CO2carbon dioxide emitted from these sources to match RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 2.6. For illustrative purposes, we have chosen to fix renewablesrenewable energy at the same level used in Fig. 4.3a. After all, supplying 50 % of the worldâs energy by renewablesrenewable energy by 2060 is a tall order. The remaining energy deficit is then assigned to CCScarbon capture and sequestration. In other words, the gold wedge in Fig. 4.5a represents the amount of energy that must be produced by combustion of fossil fuels with active CCScarbon capture and sequestration, to match the RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 2.6 emissions of CO2carbon dioxide. If the forecasts of global warmingglobal warming by the CMIP5Climate Model Intercomparison Project Phase 5GCMsgeneral circulation model are indeed accurate, then for the world to meet the goals of the Paris Climate AgreementParis Climate Agreement, not only will about 50 % of the worldâs energy need to come from renewablesrenewable energy around year 2060, but also about 38 % of global energy must be supplied by combustion of fossil fuels attached to efficient carbon capture and storage. We repeat: by 2060, 50 % of total global energy must be generated by renewablesrenewable energy and 38 % must be coupled to efficient CCScarbon capture and sequestration to match RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 2.6 and meet the EIA global energy demand forecast.11 This is a very tall order.12Fig. 4.5
World energy consumption and CO2carbon dioxide emissions, modified to meet RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 2.6. Same as Fig. 4.3, except the sum of CO2carbon dioxide emissions from coalcoal, natural gasnatural gas, and liquid fossil fuelsfossil fuels has been modified to match RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 2.6 (van Vuuren et al. 2011) starting in year 2030. The time series of consumption of energy produced by renewablesrenewable energy has been held fixed at the same value used for the RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 4.5 projection (Fig. 4.3). The remaining gap has been allocated to carbon capture and sequestration (CCS), a policy option considered by the authors of RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 2.6. See Methods for further information

It is important to emphasize that renewablesrenewable energy and CCScarbon capture and sequestration are interchangeable for Figs. 4.3 and 4.5. On one hand, CCScarbon capture and sequestration can be used to relieve some of the burden assigned to renewablesrenewable energy for achievement of RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 4.5 (Fig. 4.3a), which would be welcome if this technology has matured so that it can be implemented in a safe, efficient, cost effective manner. Alternatively, if by some happenstance renewablesrenewable energy are able to capture more than 50 % of the total energy market in 2060, then the need to couple efficient CCScarbon capture and sequestration to so much of the worldâs energy supply to match RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 2.6 (Fig. 4.5a) would be relieved.

We conclude with sobering thoughts about two technologies that are in the conversation for large-scale production of energy from renewablesrenewable energy: hydropowerhydropower and biofuelsbiofuels. In 2015, hydropower plants generated about 17 % of the worldâs electricityelectricity. Hydropower supplies about 70 % of the total electricity from renewablesrenewable energy. The two largest hydropower plants, Three Gorges Dam in China and ItaipÃº Dam on the border of Brazil and Paraguay, have enormous generating capacities of 22,500 megawatt (MW) and 14,000 MW, respectively. To place these numbers in perspective, a typical coalcoal plant can generate ~700 MW and most nuclear plants are sized at ~1000 MW.

In some instances, hydropowerhydropower has a significant GHG burden. At first glance, during operation hydropower should have a negligible GHG burden because electricityelectricity is generated from a turbine turned by the force of flowing water. Upon further consideration, there is a GHG burden involved in construction of the power plant, which can be considerable given the size of these massive facilities. A more subtle and much more costly GHG burden is the atmospheric release of CH4methane from decaying biomass in the oxygen deficient flood zone that exists upstream of these massive hydropower facilities. In some cases, particularly the tropics, this creates conditions conducive to release of large amounts of CH4methane from decaying biomass. The GHG burden of a hydropower facility can rival or even exceed that of electricity generation from a comparably sized coalcoal power plant (Fearnside 2002; Gunkel 2009). For massive hydropower plants, there can be little to no climate benefit during the first several decades of operation.

Much has been written about the climate benefit of biofuelsbiofuels and a summary of the debate would take many pages. Numerous books have been written, including Global Economic and Environmental Aspects of Biofuels (Pimentel 2012). Of all the renewablesrenewable energy, the climate benefit of biofuels is the most controversial.13 A major point of contention is how the life cycle analysis of biofuels is conducted (Muench and Guenther 2013). In addition to the net benefit for atmospheric CO2carbon dioxide of biofuels, another concern is atmospheric release of nitrous oxide (N2Onitrous oxide) from intensive application of fertilizer to grow the feedstock (Crutzen et al. 2008). As shown in Chap. 1, N2Onitrous oxide has a global warmingglobal warming potential (GWPglobal warming potential) of 265 on a 100-year horizon without consideration of carbon cyclecarbon cyclefeedbackcarbon cyclefeedback, and a GWPglobal warming potential of 298 upon consideration of this feedback (Table 1.1). Since this GHG has an atmospheric lifetime of 121 years, future society would bear the burden for many generations if the atmospheric levels of N2Onitrous oxide were to rise due to aggressive production of biofuels.

sec.title: Economic Disparity
sec.p: Achievement of either the target (1.5 Â°C) or upper limit (2 Â°C) of the global warmingglobal warming metrics of the Paris Climate TreatyParis Climate Agreement will require addressing the vast economic disparityeconomic disparity that exists in the world. Here, we illustrate this disparityeconomic disparity using measurements of night lightsnight lights obtained by the Visible Infrared Imaging Radiometer Suite (VIIRSVisible Infrared Imaging Radiometer Suite) day night band (DNB) radiometer onboard the Suomi National Polar-orbiting Partnership (NPP) platform (Hillger et al. 2013), a joint project of the US National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAANational Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration) and National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) agencies, as well as gridded populationpopulationdensity provided by NASA.

Figure 4.6 shows global populationpopulationdensity and night lightsnight lights for 2015. Population is from the NASA Socioeconomic Data and Applications Center (SEDAC) Gridded Popopulationdensitypulation of the World version 4 dataset (GPWv4) (Doxsey-Whitfield et al. 2015). Night lights are based on the annual average of cloud free scenes observed by the VIIRSVisible Infrared Imaging Radiometer Suite DNB radiometer during 2015. This instrument measures the brightness of light emitted by Earthâs surface at wavelengths between 500 and 900 nanometer (nm),14 at extremely high spatial resolution (Hillger et al. 2013; Liao et al. 2013). Spatial patterns of night lights from VIIRSVisible Infrared Imaging Radiometer Suite have been shown to exhibit high correlation with gross domestic product and electricityelectricitypower consumption (EPCelectricitypower consumption) in China, at multiple spatial scales (Shi et al. 2014).Fig. 4.6
Population and night lightsnight lights, global. Maps of population and night lights interpolated to the same 0.125Â° Ã 0.125Â° (latitude, longitude) grid. (a) Population density for 2015 obtained from the NASA SEDAC GPWv4 dataset; (b) night lights measured by the Suomi NPP VIIRSVisible Infrared Imaging Radiometer Suite DNB radiometer for cloud free scenes, averaged over all of 2015. The VIIRSVisible Infrared Imaging Radiometer Suite night lights data have been processed to remove the dominant effects of aurora borealis and fires. A logarithmic color scale has been used for both population and night lights, to better display the dynamic range of both quantities. Population density is shown in units of people per square kilometer (ppl kmâ2) and night lights are expressed in units of 10â9 watts per square cm per steradian (nW cmâ2 srâ1). See Methods for further information

The VIIRSVisible Infrared Imaging Radiometer Suite imagery in Fig. 4.6b has been adjusted so that it better represents economic conditions by removing signals due to the aurora borealis and fires (see Methods). The VIIRSVisible Infrared Imaging Radiometer Suite DNB radiometer is sensitive to any light received between 500 and 900 nm; the dominant signals other than EPCelectricitypower consumption are aurora and fires (Liao et al. 2013). Since the aurora generally occur over sparsely populated high latitude regions, a population mask as a function of latitude has been applied that effectively removes the dominant signature from aurora. The influence of wildfires has been removed using NASA Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODISModerate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer) fire count maps for 2015 (Giglio et al. 2006).

The resulting imagery depicts the geographic distribution of modern infrastructure for electricityelectricity as well as population densitypopulationdensity (Fig. 4.6). The lack of night lightsnight lights over Africa and much of India, in highly populated regions, is a matter that must be considered by those responsible for implementation of the Paris Climate AgreementParis Climate Agreement. To better illustrate the global disparityeconomic disparity in electricity consumption, Fig. 4.7 compares North America with Africa and Fig. 4.8 shows Europe (and parts of eastern Asia) and India (and parts of China). These figures provide dramatic illustration of the haves and the have nots, at least with respect to access to modern infrastructure for electricity.Fig. 4.7
Population and night lightsnight lights, North America and Africa. Same as Fig. 4.6, except these two regions have been enlarged, for visual clarityFig. 4.8
Population and night lightsnight lights, Europe and India. Same as Fig. 4.6, except these two regions have been enlarged, for visual clarity

Figure 4.9 shows scatter plots of night lightsnight lights versus population for vast regions of the globe. The United States and Europe are lit up at night. The most densely populatedpopulationdensity regions of China are approaching the night lights density of the US and Europe. While parts of India are starting to become visible from space at night, especially the Haryana and Uttar Pradesh regions that surround Delhi and major cities such as Bengaluru and Hyderabad (Fig. 4.8), the nation as a whole lags the US, Europe, and China, especially the most populated regions (Fig. 4.9). For Africa, most of the night light measurements are below the lowest value shown in the graph. The panel for Africa has fewer lines than the panels for US, Europe, China, and India because only the upper end of the night lights distribution over Africa (95th and 75th percentile, and a single median) are large enough to be displayed on the vertical scale used to display the measurements.Fig. 4.9
Scatter plots of night lightsnight lights versus population. Panels show data for the United States, Europe, China, India, and Africa for 2015. Speckles are individual VIIRSVisible Infrared Imaging Radiometer Suite night lights versus population densitypopulationdensity, from the 0.125Â° Ã 0.125Â° grid of the specific country or continent. The largest colored circles for each panel show the median values of night lights and population, after the data has been grouped into 20 bins. The smaller colored circles show the 25th and 75th percentile of the data in these bins; the black circles show the 5th and 95th percentile. The last panel compares medians for the five geographic regions. See Methods for further information

The challenge the world must overcome to slow the emission of GHGsgreenhouse gases is perhaps best encapsulated by Chinedu Ositadinma NeboNebo, Chinedu Ositadinma, Minister of Power for The Federal Republic of Nigeria, and Sospeter MuhongoMuhongo, Sospeter, Energy Minister of the United Republic of Tanzania. When asked during the 2014 US-Africa Leadersâ Summit15 whether their countries would consider development via renewable energyrenewable energy, Minister Nebo stated:
Africa is hugely in darkness. Whatever we can do to get Africa from a place of darkness to a place of light â¦ I think we should encourage that to happen.

and Minister Muhongo replied:
We in Africa, we should not be in the discussion of whether we should use coalcoal or not. In my country of Tanzania, we are going to use our natural resources because we have reserves which go beyond 5 billion tons

Implicit in the replies of Ministers NeboNebo, Chinedu Ositadinma and MuhongoMuhongo, Sospeter is the notion that for countries such as Nigeria and Tanzania to move their economies forward without relying on domestic reserves of fossil fuelfossil fuels, such that their citizens achieve a standard of living comparable to that of nations on other continents, the developed world must support this effort via payment of a so-called climate renteconomic disparityclimate rent (Jakob and Hilaire 2015; Bauer et al. 2016). The climate renteconomic disparityclimate rent is predicated on two notions: (1) the developed world is responsible for conditions that have led to the impending global warmingglobal warming crisis; (2) combustion of fossil fuelfossil fuels remains the most cost effective means of developing an economy, especially if harmful environmental effects of pollutants are not considered. For the developing world to pursue other means of developing their economies, advocates of the climate renteconomic disparityclimate rent concept would argue this route should be supported, both financially and via technology, by the developed world. Only an agreement perceived to be equitable by all participants can result in the strict limits on the future use of fossil fuelfossil fuels that will be needed to avoid dire effects of global warming.

The Paris Climate AgreementParis Climate Agreement will utilize the Green Climate Fund (GCFGreen Climate Fund),16 which was established in 2010 to assist developing countries improve their standard of living in a climate friendly manner.17 As of time of writing, the GCFGreen Climate Fund had raised $10.2 billion USD from 42 governments The GCFGreen Climate Fund goal is to collect and disburse $100 billion USD per year by 2020. While it would be foolish to sneer at such a sincere effort, and who among us can ever envision writing a check for $100 billion, much less $10.2 billion, we canât help but point out that the total population of the non-Annex I nations in the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCCUnited Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change) that have submitted conditionalIntended Nationally Determined ContributionsconditionalIntended Nationally Determined Contributions (INDCsIntended Nationally Determined Contributions)18 is approximately 4 billion people. If fully funded at the $100 billion USD goal, the GCFGreen Climate Fund would contribute only $25 per person per year to assist the developing world transform energy production to avert the adverse effects of climate change. While we can only speculate, it is likely that financial assistance at a higher level would be needed to assuage Energy Ministers such as Chinedu Ositadinma Nebo and Sospeter Muhongo.

We conclude this section by highlighting two of the successful efforts for electrification in Africa presently taking place that involve installation of solar power plants. Large-scale solar photovoltaic installations are being funded by a company named Gigawatt Global19 whose mission is to invest in the provision of renewable energyrenewable energy to Africa and other under-served, emerging markets. An 8.5 megawatt (MW), grid connected solar photovoltaic system consisting of 28,360 arrays has been operational in Rwanda since September 2014. Other projects are being developed in the Republic of Burundi and Nigeria. Each of these projects consists of a power purchase agreement (PPA) that returns revenue to the consortium of investors who finance the purchase and installation of the system. A company named Solar Reserve, which has successfully installed a 110 MW concentrated solar power plant in Nevada, is developing a 100 MW facility due to open in 2018 in South Africa.20 Successful renewable energy ventures in Africa such as those financed by Gigawatt Global and Solar Reserve provide hope that Africa, India, and the rest of the developing world can indeed manage to electrify by some means other than the combustion of fossil fuelfossil fuels.

sec.title: Emission Metrics
sec.p: In this section, the transient climate response to cumulative CO2carbon dioxide emissions (TCREtransient climate response to cumulative CO2 emissions) metric highlighted in IPCCIntergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (2013) is described, in terms of the CMIP5Climate Model Intercomparison Project Phase 5GCMsgeneral circulation model and our Empirical Model of Global Climate (EM-GC) (Canty et al. 2013). The TCREtransient climate response to cumulative CO2 emissions metric relates the rise in global mean surface temperature (GMSTglobal mean surface temperature) to the cumulative amount of anthropogenic carbon released to the atmosphere, by all sources. According to IPCCIntergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (2013), the likely range for TCREtransient climate response to cumulative CO2 emissions is 0.8 to 2.5 Â°C warming relative to pre-industrialpre-industrialbaselineGMST anomaly, per 1000 Gt C of CO2carbon dioxide emissions.21

The sensitivity of global warmingglobal warming forecasts using our EM-GC framework to the future atmospheric levels of CH4methane is also examined. This is especially important because a number of nations, including the US, are planning to fulfill their Paris INDCIntended Nationally Determined Contributions commitment by producing increasingly large percentages of electricityelectricity by the combustion of methane, rather than coalcoal. Combustion of CH4methane yields about 70 % more energy than combustion of coal, per molecule of CO2carbon dioxide released. Hence, the transition from coal to natural gasnatural gas is touted by many as being climate friendly. However, if only a small percentage of CH4methane escapes to the atmosphere at any stage prior to combustion, then the switch to natural gas can exert a climate penalty due to the large GWPglobal warming potential of CH4methane (Howarth et al. 2011).

The CMIP5Climate Model Intercomparison Project Phase 5 GCM based values of Î£CO2EMISS associated with crossing the Paris targetParis Climate Agreement seem implausibly small. As stated at the start of this section, the observed rise in ÎTGMST anomaly over the decade 2006â2015 is 0.808 Â°C.29 The climate modeling community has drawn attention to the apparent linearity between ÎTGMST anomaly and Î£CO2EMISS, particularly for the first 1000 Gt of carbon emission (MacDougall and Friedlingstein 2015). The value of Î£CO2EMISS up to end of 2010, the mid-point of the 2006â2015 time period, is 508 Gt C. If Î£CO2EMISS of 508 Gt C has been associated with 0.808 Â°C warming, and if the relation is truly linear, then the 1.5 Â°C threshold should be crossed when Î£CO2EMISS reaches 943 Gt C. This back of the envelope calculation is close only to the EM-GC values of Î£CO2EMISS given in Table 4.2 for 50 % and 66 % probability.30

Indeed, we can use another line of reasoning to suggest the CMIP5Climate Model Intercomparison Project Phase 5 GCM based values of Î£CO2EMISS associated with crossing the Paris targetParis Climate Agreement are too low. As noted in the introduction to this section, IPCCIntergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (2013) stated the likely range for TCREtransient climate response to cumulative CO2 emissions is 0.8â2.5 Â°C warming per 1000 Gt C of CO2carbon dioxide emissions. Our probabilistic projection of ÎTGMST anomaly shown in Fig. 4.11, for the point where Î£CO2EMISS = 1000 Gt C, is bounded by 0.8 and 2.4 Â°C, in near perfect agreement with the range stated by (IPCCIntergovernmental Panel on Climate Change2013). Conversely, the CMIP5Climate Model Intercomparison Project Phase 5 GCM estimate that the 1.5 Â°C threshold will be crossed when Î£CO2EMISS = 633 Gt CO2carbon dioxide implies a warming of 2.4 Â°C per 1000 Gt C. Simulations conducted in the EM-GC framework suggest this value is possible but highly unlikely.

Science is driven by reproducibility of results. As stated at the end of Chap. 2, we urge that more effort be devoted to assessing GCM-based forecasts of global warmingglobal warming using energy balance approaches such as our EM-GC framework. It is our sincere hope that others will evaluate and publish values of Î£CO2EMISS and Î£CO2carbon dioxide-eqEMISS, such as those in Tables 4.2 and 4.3, using various model frameworks. Time will tell whether our estimates of Î£CO2EMISS and Î£CO2carbon dioxide-eqEMISS survive the scrutiny of others. In the interim, we urge policy makers to tentatively consider that achieving the target of the Paris Climate AgreementParis Climate Agreement, via the existing INDCIntended Nationally Determined Contributions pledges, may indeed be a realistic goal.

sec.title: CH4
sec.p: One final complication must be addressed: the potential rise of atmospheric CH4methane. The present globally averaged mixing ratio of CH4methane, the second most important anthropogenic GHG, is 1.84 ppm.31 Projected future values of CH4methane diverge by an enormous amount among the four RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway scenarios (Fig. 2.1).

The RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway projections of CH4methane reflect the large uncertainty in future emissions. The RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 2.6 scenario (van Vuuren et al. 2011) projects a CH4methane mixing ratio of 1.37 ppm in 2060 (Table 4.1; see also Fig. 2.1). Atmospheric CH4methane has numerous human-related sources (Fig. 1.9). The RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 2.6 design projects a 26 % decline of CH4methane by 2060, due to stringent controls on human release from all sources other than agricultureagriculture. Their projection considers the climate benefit of diet, particularly global consumption of more plant based foods (Stehfest et al. 2009; Pierrehumbert and Eshel 2015). The RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 4.5 scenario (Thomson et al. 2011) projects a CH4methane mixing ratio of 1.80 ppm in 2060 (Table 4.2; Fig. 4.12), close to todayâs value. The RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 4.5 design entails the use of a market pricing mechanism to stabilize global emissions of CH4methane (and CO2carbon dioxide, as well) at close to present level. Finally, the RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 8.5 projection has atmospheric CH4methane at 2.7 ppm in 2060 and continuing to rise, unabated, until end of century (Fig. 4.12).Fig. 4.12
Impact of CH4methane on EM-GC projections using RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 4.5. (a) Time series of atmospheric CH4methane from observations (Dlugokencky et al. 2009), RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 4.5 (blue, lowest curve) (Thomson et al. 2011) and RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 8.5 (red, highest curve) (Riahi et al. 2011) as well as various other âblendedâ scenarios for CH4methane that are linear combinations of RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 4.5 and RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 8.5; (b) probability that the rise in ÎTGMST anomaly in 2060 stays below 1.5 Â°C (gold diamonds) and 2.0 Â°C (blue squares) relative to pre-industrialpre-industrial, computed using RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 4.5 combined with one of the blended CH4methane scenarios and plotted as a function of CH4methane in 2060; (c) same as (b), except for year 2100

As noted in the introduction, the transition of production of electricityelectricity from coalcoal to natural gasnatural gas32 is touted by many as being climate friendly because combustion of CH4methane yields 70 % more energy than combustion of coal, per molecule of CO2carbon dioxide released to the atmosphere. The Clean Power Plan Clean Power Plan (CPP) proposed by the US Environmental Protection Agency33 places limits on the abundance of CO2carbon dioxide that can be emitted by electric generating units (EGUs) within each of the 50 states, by year 2030. To make a long story short, the US CPP facilitates the large-scale transition away from coal-fired EGUs to either natural gas or renewable EGUs. At time of writing, the US CPP is still being litigated. Of course, this policy is driven by the availability of a large domestic supply of CH4methane that is produced by horizontal fracturing of shale gas (i.e., frackingnatural gasfracking). Throughout the US, aging coal-fired EGUs are being replaced by new natural gas facilities, such as a 990 MW natural gas EGU scheduled to open in Brandywine, Maryland during 2018.34 We mention the Brandywine plant to emphasize that in the US, market forces are driving replacement of coal-fired EGUs with natural gas units. Globally, however, atmospheric release of CO2carbon dioxide from coal has been growing faster than atmospheric release of CO2carbon dioxide from methane (Fig. 4.1).

The leakage of CH4methane, at any point from extraction to just prior to combustion, tips the scales towards natural gasnatural gas imposing a climate penalty rather than providing climate benefit (Howarth et al. 2011). Upon consideration of the latest values for the GWPglobal warming potential of CH4methane from IPCCIntergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (2013), the break-even points are leakage of 6.9 % CH4methane for GWPglobal warming potential on a 100-year time horizon and leakage of 2.3 % CH4methane for GWPglobal warming potential on a 20-year time horizon.35

Choice of time horizon for the GWPglobal warming potential of CH4methane is critical for deciding whether frackingnatural gasfracking in the US provides climate benefit or imposes climate penalty (Howarth 2014; Brandt et al. 2014). Table 4.4 shows estimates of the percentage of CH4methane leaked from active production sites, relative to daily production rates, from six selected recent studies that sample a large majority of the active natural gasnatural gas extraction locations in the US. There is large variability in the estimated leakage rates. Regardless, one would conclude a more dire situation exists, with the climate balance likely swinging towards a penalty for frackingnatural gasfracking, upon use of the 2.3 % leakage rate tipping point (Howarth 2014). Conversely, one would conclude an overall climate benefit from frackingnatural gasfracking upon use of the 6.9 % break-even point and some of the measured leakage rates given in Table 4.4 (Brandt et al. 2014). Quantification of leakage of CH4methane from production facilities will continue for quite some time, as will the debate regarding which leakage rate threshold should be used, as the community attempts to obtain consensus on whether frackingnatural gasfracking is friend or foe to climate. In some sense, weâd prefer to use GWPglobal warming potential over a ~45-year time horizon, since our primary focus is projection of global warmingglobal warming out to 2060. Here we use another approach to assess the impact of CH4methane on the Paris Climate AgreementParis Climate Agreement. The future projections of CH4methane offered by RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 4.5 (Thomson et al. 2011) and RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 8.5 (Riahi et al. 2011) are vastly different. Figure 4.12a compares these two projections along with various âblendedâ scenarios, which are linear combinations of the two extremes. Simulations of the future rise in ÎTGMST anomaly have been conducted in the EM-GC framework for the six CH4methane scenarios shown in Fig. 4.12a; all other GHG and aerosol precursor values are based on RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 4.5. Not only do these calculations provide a means for assessing the importance of controlling CH4methane leakage, but they also serve as a surrogate for quantifying the importance of future release of CH4methane from Arctic permafrost (Koven et al. 2011) (provided, of course, that atmospheric CH4methane stays bounded by the two extremes shown in Fig. 4.12a). As noted in Chap. 1, the present source of CH4methane from Arctic permafrost is small on a global scale (Kirschke et al. 2013), but this could change due to feedbacks in the climate system (Koven et al. 2011).

Figures 4.12b, c quantify the impact of future levels of atmospheric CH4methane on achieving the Paris thresholds. Figure 4.12b shows the cumulative probability that ÎTGMST anomaly in year 2060, ÎT2060, will remain below the Paris targetParis Climate Agreement of 1.5 Â°C (gold diamonds) or the Paris upper limit of 2.0 Â°C (blue squares). Figure 4.12c shows similar projections, but for 2100. Results are plotted as a function of the atmospheric mixing ratio of CH4methane for the respective end year. Otherwise, the calculations are calculated in an identical manner to that described for the EM-GC, RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 4.5 entry in Table 2.1. The symbols associated with lowest value of CH4methane shown in Fig. 4.12b, c have the same numerical values as the appropriate entries for the EM-GC, RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 4.5 row of Table 2.1.

The cumulative probabilities shown in Fig. 4.12 illustrate the importance of controlling future levels of atmospheric CH4methane. If the goal is to achieve the Paris targetParis Climate Agreement of 1.5 Â°C warming, the EM-GC calculations suggest a ~79 % probability this will happen out to 2060, and a ~75 % probability out to 2100, if all GHGsgreenhouse gases follow RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 4.5. If atmospheric CH4methane rises dramatically along the RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 8.5 route and the future atmospheric abundance CO2carbon dioxide falls along the RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 4.5 trajectory, then the respective probabilities for achieving the Paris targetParis Climate Agreement decline to 58.3 % and 43.3 % in 2060 and 2100, respectively. Quantification of the impact of CH4methane on achieving the Paris targetParis Climate Agreement is provided for various other pathways, based on the points that lie in between the far left (RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 4.5) and far right (RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 8.5) entries. Finally, if atmospheric CO2carbon dioxide can indeed be placed along the RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 4.5 trajectory, then the EM-GC calculations indicate atmospheric CH4methane will likely not interfere with keeping global warmingglobal warming below the Paris 2.0 Â°C upper limit (Fig. 4.12c).

sec.title: Paris Climate Agreement, Beacon of Hope
sec.p:
Even though society has obtained enormous benefit from the energy released by the combustion of fossil fuelsfossil fuels, the relation between human activity, rising CO2carbon dioxide, and global warmingglobal warming is demonstrably clear (Chap. 1). We have used our Empirical Model of Global Climate to show that, if future abundances of CO2carbon dioxide, CH4methane, and N2Onitrous oxide follow the trajectory of the RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 4.5 scenario (Thomson et al. 2011), there is greater than 95 % probability the rise in global mean surface temperature during the rest of this century will stay below 2 Â°C warming (relative to pre-industrialpre-industrialbaselineGMST anomaly) and a ~75 % chance future warming will stay below 1.5 Â°C warming (Chap. 2). Our analysis of the INDCsIntended Nationally Determined Contributions that constitute the Paris Climate AgreementParis Climate Agreement (Chap. 3) show that GHG emissions will remain below RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 4.5 out to 2060 if:
conditional as well as unconditional pledgesIntended Nationally Determined Contributionsunconditional are met
reductions in GHG emissions needed to achieve the Paris commitments, which generally extend to 2030, are propagated forward to 2060
The Paris Climate AgreementParis Climate Agreement, as presently constituted, provides a beacon of hope that climate catastrophe can be avoided.

The Paris INDCsIntended Nationally Determined Contributions, with rare exception, extend only to 2030. It is essential the world begin planning for a 2060 future. Market forces, driven by the low cost availability of natural gasnatural gas, will facilitate achievement or near achievement of the Paris commitments in some nations, such as the US, without particularly a aggressive transition to renewable energyrenewable energy. However, the gap between market driven production of energy by the combustion of fossil fuelsfossil fuels and the limit of RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 4.5 grows dramatically between 2030 and 2060 (Fig. 4.2). Assuming a 5.7 % share of nuclear energynuclear energy in 2060, then achievement of RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 4.5 emissions of CO2carbon dioxide requires 50 % of global energy to be produced by renewablesrenewable energy in 2060 (Fig. 4.3). The global climate models used by IPCCIntergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC 2013) indicate the RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 2.6 emission trajectory has to be followed to keep warming below 2.0 Â°C. If this is indeed true, then 88 % of the global demand of energy by 2060 will need to be produced by methods with negligible impact on atmospheric GHGsgreenhouse gases (Fig. 4.5).

Many communities, towns, and nations have embraced the challenge. Green Mountain CollegeGreen Mountain College, Vermont in the state of Vermont has a credible plan in place to obtain 100 % of the energy consumed on campus by renewable sources in 2020.36 The central element of this effort is a biomass plant that uses locally harvested woodchips to generate heat. SamsÃ¶, DenmarkSamsÃ¶, Denmark, an island of about 4000 inhabitants, has a net negative carbon footprint thanks to 22 massive wind turbines, most of which are owned by members of the community.37 Germany is planning to increase the share of total, nation-wide energy consumed that is provided by renewablesrenewable energy from 12.6 % in 2015 to 60 % by 2050.38 The German effort is multifaceted, involving various forms of renewable energyrenewable energy as well as state-of-the-art building efficiency standards. In Sect. 4.3, solar energy projects in Nigeria, Rwanda, and South Africa were described. It is incumbent the rest of the world embrace and emulate the efforts of Green Mountain CollegeGreen Mountain College, Vermont, SamsÃ¶SamsÃ¶, Denmark, Germany, the solar projects in Africa, and so many other communities, towns, and nations that are actively transitioning to renewablesrenewable energy. Fifty percent of total global energy by renewablesrenewable energy in year 2060 is a very tall pole. As populations expandpopulationgrowth and standards of living rise, 50 % renewablesrenewable energy in 2060 will be needed to have a reasonably good chance of achieving the goals of the Paris Climate AgreementParis Climate Agreement.

Briefly, degeneracy of the climate system refers to the fact that the prior ÎTGMST anomaly record can be fit nearly equally well assuming large climate feedback and strong aerosol cooling, or weak climate feedback and little to no aerosol cooling. Regardless of what had happened in the past, the radiative impact of aerosolsaerosols will be diminishing in the future, due to public health concerns that are leading to steep reductions in the emission of aerosol precursors. If we assume the climate feedback inferred from the climate record will persist into the future, then projections of ÎTGMST anomaly found using the large climate feedback simulation will exceed those found using weak feedback. The community that studies radiative effects of aerosols is not close to a consensus on which of these two scenarios is more likely to be correct.

The use of the color bar to show probabilistic projections of ÎTGMST anomaly is explained in much greater detail in Chap. 2. Briefly, the pure white region of Fig. 4.11a is the most probably outcome for forecast ÎTGMST anomaly using RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 8.5, assuming climate feedback and ocean heatocean heat export inferred from the climate record persist into the future. The dark blue region shows plausible but unlikely projections of modest warming and the dark red shows plausible but unlikely projections of strong warming. Probabilities associated with modest warming are close to unity (i.e., it is nearly certain the climate system will warm at least this much) and those associated with strong warming are close to zero (i.e., it is unlikely the climate system will warm to this extent).

As explained in prior footnote, dark red colors represent plausible but unlikely values of strong warming. Since it is unlikely climate will warm to this extent, the dark red color is associated with the low probability of 0.05. The light grey line connects all model outcomes probabilities of 0.05. Since there is only a 5 % chance it will warm this much, there is a 95 % chance that warming will fall below the grey line.
